title: Variables and Data Types
content:
Introduction to Variables

Variables are containers for storing data values. In Python, a variable is created the moment you assign a value to it:

# Creating variables
name = "John"
age = 25
height = 1.75

Python has no command for declaring a variable. A variable is created the moment you first assign a value to it.

Variable Naming Rules

  • A variable name must start with a letter or the underscore character
  • A variable name cannot start with a number
  • A variable name can only contain alpha-numeric characters and underscores (A-z, 0-9, and _)
  • Variable names are case-sensitive (age, Age and AGE are three different variables)

Examples of valid variable names:

my_var = "John"
_my_var = "John"
myVar = "John"
MYVAR = "John"
my_var_1 = "John"

Python Data Types

In Python, there are several built-in data types:

1. Text Type

str: String literals can be enclosed by either double or single quotes:

message = "Hello, World!"
name = 'John'

2. Numeric Types

int: Integer numbers without decimal part:

age = 25
quantity = -10

float: Numbers with decimal part:

height = 1.75
temperature = -2.5

complex: Complex numbers with real and imaginary parts:

z = 1 + 2j

3. Boolean Type

bool: Boolean values (True or False):

is_student = True
is_adult = False

4. Sequence Types

list: Ordered and changeable collections:

fruits = ["apple", "banana", "cherry"]

tuple: Ordered and unchangeable collections:

coordinates = (10, 20)

5. Mapping Type

dict: Key-value pairs:

person = {"name": "John", "age": 25}

Checking the Type

You can get the data type of any object by using the type() function:

x = 5
print(type(x))  # Output: <class 'int'>

Type Conversion

You can convert from one type to another using constructor functions:

# Convert from int to float
x = 5
float_x = float(x)  # Result: 5.0

# Convert from float to int
y = 3.14
int_y = int(y)  # Result: 3 (truncates decimal part)

# Convert to string
z = str(5)  # Result: "5"
